channel.title: Portfolios on Mark LeBoeuf
channel.description: Recent content in Portfolios on Mark LeBoeuf

item.title: Two Flavors of Parallel Simulation
item.description: Tired of waiting around for your simulations to finish? Run them in parallel! This post covers two seperate ways to add parallelism to your R code.

item.title: Choosing a Fantasy Football Quarterback
item.description: Aaron Rodgers or Tom Brady? Carson Wentz or Drew Brees? Choosing the right Fantasy Football QB each week is challenging. To remove some of the guesswork from the decision-making process, I devised an approach that’s worked well over the past few seasons. Read on to learn more about using the Beta Distribution to pick your weekly starting QB.

item.title: Predicting First Year Fantasy Football Points in Rookies
item.description: Drafting a rookie in Fantasy Football can be a risky move, but it can pay huge dividends if you happen to snag a diamond in the rough. After accounting for a player’s draft position, do physical attributes (height/weight) and combine performance (40 yard dash, bench press, etc.) provide any additional explanatory power of points scored during a player’s first NFL season? I’ll explore this question for rookie Running Backs and Wide Receivers.

item.title: Time Series Outlier Detection
item.description: This post covers a straightforward approach to detecting and replacing outliers in time series.

item.title: Forecasting with External Regressors
item.description: This post focuses on some of my favorite things – data, sports, and forecasting – and will outline how to leverage external regressors when creating forecasts. We’ll do some webscraping in R and Python to create our dataset, and then forecast how many people will visit Tom Brady’s wikipedia page.

item.title: Feature Selection for the Wine Connoisseur
item.description: Feature selection is an integral part of machine learning, and this post explores what happens when lots of irrelevant features are added into the modeling process. We’ll also identify which algorithms are affected the most by such features. These questions will be addressed as we build a classifier and try to predict which wines we’ll like based on their chemical properties. So pour yourself a glass of Pinot Noir and fire up your R terminal!

item.title: Keras End-to-End Tutorial
item.description: Most Keras tutorials I’ve come across outline the process of creating a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with built-in datasets. While this is a great place to begin, there’s a bit more involved in terms of pre-processing when starting out with just a bunch of pictures. This post provides a quick, end-to-end walkthrough of how to implement a CNN with Keras in Python from scratch.

item.title: Monte Carlo Power Calculations for Mixed Effects Models
item.description: That’s a dense title – Monte Carlo Simulation, Power, Mixed-Effect models. Each of these topics could be their own post. However, I’m going to discuss their interrelations in the context of experimental power and keep everything high-level. The goal is to get an intuitive idea of how we can leverage simulation to provide sample size estimates for experiments with nested data.

item.title: Early Trend Detection
item.description: Identifying a trend before it starts is a major area of focus in the analytics realm, because it can inform key business decisions yet remains extremely difficult. This post outlines one trend-detection method in an effort to predict where a stock’s price will go in the future.

item.title: Random Forest Prediction Intervals
item.description: Take a stroll through the random forest to learn how to quantify uncertainty in your predictions with one of the more popular applied machine learning algorithms.

item.title: R Exception Handling
item.description: Exception handling is a critical component of any data science workflow. You write code. It breaks. You create exceptions. Repeat. From my experience, a point of confusion for new R users is how to handle exceptions, which I believe is more intuitive in Python (at least initially). This post provides a practical overview of how to handle exceptions in R by first illustrating the concept in Python.

item.title: Establishing Causality with Counterfactual Prediction
item.description: Sometimes a controlled experiment isn’t an option yet you want to establish causality. This post outlines a method for quantifying the effects of an intervention via counterfactual predictions.
